segments.text: My name is Dominic Mankit Lamb.
You can get the spelling later, right?
And I hold a number of positions.
Most of them are in the Woodlands.
I'm the founding director of the Center for Biotechnology at Baylor College of Medicine, which is located in the Woodlands.
It's founded in 1985 and
And the building was completed in 1987 on an 11 acre of land donated to Baylor by George Mitchell.
I'm also professor of biotechnology, cell biology, and ophthalmology at Baylor College of Medicine.

Additionally, in 1984, I co-founded Houston Biotechnology Incorporated, which is a company based on an invention that a colleague of mine, Dr. Jared Emery, and I discovered when we were professors at Baylor.
And on the basis of that discovery,
a company was founded, started by Baylor in Houston, and in 1986 we moved up to the Woodlands.
And what was the nature of the discovery?
Could you describe it a bit?
Yeah, I will talk about each operation because otherwise it's very confusing.
And then in 1989,

I also founded another company based on Baylor's, another technology that I developed while at Baylor College of Medicine, and that company is called GES Pharmaceutical, for genetic engineer systems, Pharmaceuticals Inc. That company is also located in the Woodlands, and I'm a director of that company.
A little bit of the background, I was born in mainland China, but moved to- my whole family emigrated to Hong Kong when I was four months old, and I grew up in Hong Kong.
At sixteen I went to college in Canada, first in mathematics, and then I did a master's
theoretical physics before I became interested in medicine and especially in pharma research.
So I did my doctorate at University of Toronto and then upon finishing that I went to Harvard Medical School where I worked with two
professors there, Dr. and Dr. David Hubel, who later on in 1981 received the Nobel Prize in medicine.
I stayed on at Harvard until 1977 as an assistant professor at Harvard.
In 1977, I moved to Baylor College of Medicine to head a program in their ophthalmology department.
It was in that environment that I discovered with my colleagues in 1984 a treatment for secondary cataract, or more accurately, a preventive for secondary cataract.
And this is based on a new technology called hybridoma technology, which is the production of monoclonal antibodies.
in vitro.
Using that technology, we found that we can produce antibodies when they are coupled to certain types of toxins would destroy the cells that cause secondary cataract.
Now very briefly, what is secondary cataract?
Secondary, we all know what primary cataract is.
Primary cataract is the

is when the length of the eye becomes clouded because the cells started to die then that obstructs the passage of light between the outside world and the back of the eye which is the retina when that happened then normally the patient would go to the ophthalmologist which
who, in a half an hour operation, would remove the lens and sometimes put in the artificial lens.
Yeah, my mother had that done.
She has 20-20 vision now.
It's incredible.
It's the most popular surgical procedure in the United States, accounting for about 1.2 million cases a year in the United States alone.
And it works extremely well most of the time.
There's only one major complication with the procedure, which is called extracapsular extraction.
And that complication has to do that the surgeon rarely can remove all the cells that cause cataract.
So there are always a few cells left.

that then try to form another lens and they don't form it successfully so again they instead of forming a transparent lens they form what is like a frosted lens so that light again is obstructed from or images are obstructed at that place and in 1984 i thought that if

one could have a medicine such as a very specific antibody which at the end of the surgery could be injected into the eye to destroy all the cells that could not be, the minuscule amount of cells that could not be destroyed by, could not be removed by surgery.
That would clear the problem and this was what we did.

This product is now going into clinical trials, and we expect it to have a market in the United States alone of hundreds of millions of dollars, because it will be used in about a million patients a year, and if one charges a couple hundred dollars, that's already 200 million dollars.
How long is the processing period?
What?
How long will the test period be before you can release it?
Oh, probably another few years before we finish the testing, clinical testing.
This is a brochure about Houston Biotechnology, which is outdated.
It's two years old, but it gives you some idea of what has happened and how we raise money and so on.
I'm also...
Now, in 1985, when we were finding, trying to find a permanent place to locate Houston Biotechnology, we were asked to look at the Woodlands by Mr. Mike Richmond and Dr. Gottlieb, David Gottlieb.
And we decided that, especially because of the vision of Mr.
Mitchell and also the natural beauty of the woodlands as a living, as a community in which to live, that this would be a desirable place to move.
There's only one hitch that's a problem is that at that time there was not even research forest road.
There was no high tech research or industry here at all.
And we felt that
For high tech industry, one must have a significant amount of intellectual interactions and activities here.

And so Mr. Mitchell, in particular, convinced Baylor College of Medicine that as a community leader, that maybe they would build a center for biotechnology out in the woodlands around which new biotechnology companies can flourish.
can be established and flourish.
Did you know this was happening before you made the decision to move?
What was happening?
Oh yeah, both moved at the same time.
The decision was made at the same time, that if Baylor would do that, I would move up here and build the first company, biotech company.
And that was all agreed upon in 1985.
after which we raised $26 million for Houston Biotechnology.
Did Mitchell's organization help you in that?
In raising the money?
In raising capital?
No, not as much in raising $26 million.
They put in some money in the earlier round.
as venture capital money.
But the major amount of money was raised by Sherson Lehman Hutton in a public offering of R&D partnership.
So while I remain to this day as the chairman of Houston Biotechnology, I was also asked to be the founding director of the Center for Biotechnology.
put up all the money for the building, and I was responsible for hiring the people into the center, which now has about maybe 80 or so full-time members now in the three years that we are here.
That's a lot of development.
And now one reason that Baylor agreed to do this was that, as you remember,
when the energy prices took a dive in 1983 or so, Houston suddenly woke up to the fact that you could not live on a single industry, namely the energy industry, that you had to diversify.
So the city attempted to
than to see what are the industries that Houston can diversify into.
One area is obviously in space because of the NASA, another area is in shipping because of the port, and then another area is in petrochemical again because of energy related.
But a very important area that

suddenly became commercially very attractive is the biopharmaceutical area, because the Texas Medical Center in Houston is the largest medical center in the world, in United States anyway, maybe in the world, it's hard to know.
However, that has always flourished as almost a pharentropic activity.
When people make a lot of money, like Collins and Jones, they donate the money, but nobody has ever tried to commercialize the research and medical products that come out of that.
So Houston Biotechnology was, in a way, the first one that formalized the beginning of this biopharmaceutical commercialization effort, spearheaded by the medical center.
decided that the medical center area is really too congested to sustain the long-term industry.
And therefore, the Woodlands, because of Mr. Mitchell and because his location, was chosen by us to be the place where hopefully the biopharmaceutical industry in Houston would flourish.
What have been your relations to the Houston Medical Center itself?
Well, I'm still a full professor with Baylor College of Medicine.
And I still go down to committee meetings and so on.
I'm still a chairman of the department.
But it's just that it's up here.

So the relationship, though, is basically still cordial and very close, and you would expect it to be... Oh, the relationship is very good, and in fact, Baylor is responsible for all the operating expenses up here.
It's a full-fledged center owned by Baylor.
No, this particular building is Houston Biotechnology.
This is the commercial side.
At 30,000 square feet, this is for the commercialization of biotechnology.
of forming products.
On the other side is better culture medicine.
Yeah, they're two separate, physically and financially and administratively distinct.
So this is happening with the blessing of the Houston Medical Center and the downtown community, the Texas Medical Center.
And with Baylor College of Medicine.
Yeah.
Yeah, explicitly.
Yes, that's right.
And subsequent to us, as you know, University of Texas has built a cryobiology center here.
Yeah, we saw that.
And Life Cell is here, another company.
started by University of Texas.
F.D.
Anderson has founded a company called Argus that has moved up here now.
Okay, and the incentive for those moves has come primarily from what threw us through?
Through the woodlands or through yourself?
Well, it's probably both.
You know, as you know, most people don't like to take the lead.
And, you know, when we first came here, the road has to be built.
There was no road.
The forest, we have to...
to bring in sewage and telephone lines.
This is the first building in the research forest, right here.
And so, once I was willing with my colleagues to build these first two buildings, it was much easier to attract other companies and institutions to come up.
Now are these your buildings, may I ask, or are they the Woodlands?
Well, this building is owned by the Woodlands, but we lease.
That building is owned by Baylor.
Did Mr. Mitchell donate the land for that building?
Yes, for Baylor's.
And they own this one?
They own this one, then we lease.
Does your company now have any direct involvement or relationships to the other medical companies and industries that are developing around you?
Yes.
For example, GES Pharmaceutical, which I founded last year.
Now, Houston Biotechnology exclusively, yes, is specifically developing drugs against eye diseases.
GES, which I founded last year, is to develop drugs against other kinds of diseases, such as neurological and cardiovascular diseases.
And then the Center for Biotechnology has founded another company last year called Triplex Pharmaceutical Corporation, T-R-I-P-L-E-X.
And that one is, you know, to use a new kind of therapy to treat diseases.
So we are
We are beginning to establish a large number of companies.
We also work with HAAC on different projects.
We collaborated on a project with using laser to sculpture the cornea to correct nearsightedness and farsightedness.
So you really see a sort of a complementary, symbiotic medical community or something developing in this area?
Yes, biomedical community.
That has a great deal of promise.
I think Baylor College of Medicine is a national leader in this, a leader in having academia and industry work side by side each other, as you know.
At A&M, there has been a lot of difficulty trying to commercialize A&M's products.
But Baylor really has been a pioneer.
And universities from Stanford to Harvard come here to see how this is done.
Oh, which are private institutions.
Is that the distinction, the fact that A&M, for example, is a state-supported institution, whereas Baylor and Harvard?
Yes, that's partly true.
But of course, Harvard, Rockefeller, and Stanford are also private.
Right.
And they also have problem with dealing with between academia and industry.
Yeah.
Being private, it makes it more flexible.
But it's not the only reason, difficulty with commercialization of one's technologies.
Do you have any future directions now that you're
heading your company or your two companies?
Yes, we do.
Our goal is to make the Baylor Center for Biotechnology one of the leading biotech centers in the country in research efforts.
And in that regard, we have already attracted a number of first-rate scientists, so we are making the right first step in that.
The other companies that I found, obviously, the priority is to have our first product in the market.
Now, GES Pharmaceutical already has products for screening drugs that are available.
Some of those will be licensed to US and Japanese companies and European companies.
But Houston Biotechnology,
is developing therapeutic agents, which take a long time.
And we have built what we believe is the first FDA-approved GMP drug manufacturing facilities in Houston for biological materials, like proteins here in Houston.
And that takes a long time, and we have to go through the regulatory affairs in getting drugs approved.
But hopefully, within the next five years, one can see a number of important products that will emerge from the woodlands.
Not just from our company, but other companies as well.
This effort with HARC, is it similar?
The effort with HARC is mostly a research effort.
It has not been a conventional effort.
Again, HARC is a non-profit organization.
But I think in the future we'll have some commercial efforts.
What do you see as the dynamics of the woodlands now in terms of its development?
How is this going to affect the development of the woodlands and the Houston society generally?
How does this fit, say, the research part?
Well, I think the woodlands is already, it certainly lags behind the research triangle part.
Yeah, that's a pattern we've heard mentioned a lot.
In North Carolina and also the Silicon Valley area.
You see something like that happening here, though?
Yeah, there's no question that we see something like that around here, especially with respect to biotechnology.
Now, it's unlikely to happen in microelectronics or telecommunication or computers because we're too far behind to really catch up on that.
The last chance we had was compact.
It didn't move here.

they didn't move here but anyway um however in biotechnology where the field is still very in this infant stage that i think that the woodlands we are trying to build the woodlands as the gulf coast equivalent to the east coast and west coast establishment so we want to establish this as the third coast for biotechnology biopharmaceutical
Your home is in the woodlands?
Yes, I live five minutes from here.
Do you find the environment itself an attractive recruiting mechanism to bring people in?

Well, you know, other than having the privilege and pleasure of working with Mrs. Mitchell, the major reason why I moved here, and also many of my colleagues, is because the woodlands is such a great area to live in and to raise a family.
I have
two children and they go to the very good public schools.
I think we're still an infant in terms of the number of intellectual powers over here.
We're new.
However, it's an environment where people can live
among the woods and in a place that's safe, that's still affordable, I would think that we're second to none in the nation.
And I think that's a major strength that will help us continue to recruit the top-notch people to December.
Not only as not only famous and established people, but as much as more
the brilliant young people.
Because most of those people can't afford to buy a house in California.
That's right.
They want to have a family.
So I think this is a major strength.
And as you know, they're over, they're probably close to 200 PhD and MD
doctorate-level people in the woodlands.
Which is an unusual concentration in this part of the country.
And it's still, while it's small, it's a very good nucleus on which to build our strength for the future.
So I'm very optimistic about the future.
I'm enthusiastic about building the woodlands.
Good.
That's probably a good place to stop.
Okay.
Thank you.
